biogHist.abstract: Katakutu was established in 1958, as an independently-managed hostel in Mount Lawley to accommodate young Aboriginal men coming to Perth to work from rural Western Australia. In 1961, Katukutu moved nearby into premises that had been Alvan House and by 1966 was run by the Baptist Union. It became a government-run facility by 1974, possibly also accommodating students, and operated until at least 1982.
biogHist.p: Katakutu was established in 1958 by Mr and Mrs Robert and Betty McKeich, to accommodate young Aboriginal men from the country who came to Perth for training, work or study. Its name means, 'To the top'. At that time, Katakutu was supported by a committee formed from members of the Dalkeith Baptist Church and some people from other denominations. Beginning in rented premises in Almondbury Street, Mount Lawley, Katakutu moved in 1961 to premises at 28 Alvan Street that had been acquired by the Baptist Union from the Department of Native Welfare.
By 1966, Katakutu was under the control of the Baptist Union of Western Australia, with management by the Baptist Aborigines Mission committee.
In a survey in 1971, Katukutu was described as being run along principles consistent with a 'fundamentalist Baptist' approach.

In 1975, Katakutu provided short-term hostel accommodation for up to fourteen male Aboriginal youth of working age, with an average length of stay being nine months. At that stage, facilities at Katukutu included: six bedrooms (four doubles and two sleeping three or more), three bathrooms and toilets; a lounge and dining room; separate staff toilet; table tennis/pool table; television, radiogram and library.

Katukutu operated under a funding agreement with the Department for Native Welfare until 1972 and then the Department for Community Welfare until 1973. By 1974, Katukutu was government-run for an unknown period, and possibly accommodated students as well as young Aboriginal workers. By 2004, the premises at Alvan Street were used as a Parent Help Centre.

chronItem.event: Address - Katukutu was situated at 17 Almondbury Road, Mount Lawley
Address - Katukutu was situated at 28 Alvan Street, on the corner of Queen's Crescent, Mount Lawley

descriptiveNote.p: Katukutu Employment Hostel was run by members of the Baptist Union (Mr and Mrs McKeich) from 1958, but it is possible that the Baptist Union was not formally responsible for the governance of Katukutu until it moved to the Alvan House premises in 1961.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Department for Community Welfare, State of Western Australia (1972 - 1985)

descriptiveNote.p: The Department for Community Welfare ran Katukutu Employment Hostel from 1974 to at least 1982 and possibly longer.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Robert McKeich, who had established Katukutu Employment Hostel, had also been involved in establishing Cundeelee.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Department of Native Welfare, State of Western Australia (1955 - 1972)

descriptiveNote.p: Katukutu Employment Hostel was managed by the Baptist Union under agreement with the Department of Native Welfare.
Katukutu Employment Hostel moved into the premises previously known as Alvan House.
Parent Help Centre (2004? - ) was located in what had been theKatukutu Employment Hostel.

archref.abstract: 'Katukutu Employment Hostel, Mt Lawley [excerpt]' is an excerpt from the Department for Community Development's finding aid, Signposts: A Guide for Children and Young People in Care in WA from 1920. It gives historical information from a 1971 survey that included the Hostel.
archref.note: Published with the permission of the Department for Child Protection and Family Support
